Gujarat, meanwhile, were handed their first loss of the season after an eight-wicket trouncing at the hands of the Sunrisers Hyderabad. One aspect that has hurt GT has been their opening stand which hasn't survived a powerplay so far. In the four games, their first-wicket stands have been worth: 4, 2, 32 and 24. Left-hander Sai Sudarshan batting at No.3 now provides break in the run of right-handers at the top. Matthew Wade will likely make way for Rahmanullah Gurbaz, considering his inability to get starts so far and factoring in the latter's superior record in Asia. Gurbaz, in 68 innings, has amassed 1620 runs at an average of 24.17, striking at a dangerous 151.82 as opposed to Wade's 93.36. The middle-order too has been needing to get among the runs with David Miller yet to fire.  Samson too has had little success after the first game; it's evident he's struggling when pace is taken off in what has been his slowest start to a season in the last six years. His game has been found wanting on slower tracks in the past, and with tracks set to slow down as the season progress, his form could be a cause of concern for the Royals. Shimron Hetmyer's display of power and skill in the death, though, has done RR a world of good. He's striking at close to 200 and has contributed in all four games so far. Gujarat will want to contain him in the death, with Rashid having the wood over him, but GT may have vital strategic decisions to make as to how Rashid should be used.  When: RR vs GT, April 14, 19:30 IST  Where: Dr DY Patil Sports Academy, NaviMumbai  What to expect: The CSK-RCB game was played on a used wicket, with it being so dry that the dust on it was palpable. The spinners played a crucial role in the second innings with 7 wickets shared between Mahesh Theekshana and Ravindra Jadeja. If a similar wicket is on offer, both sides have the arsenal to use it to their advantage. The average first innings total has come down from 177 in 11 games in the first week (March 26-April 3) to 163 in 10 in the second week (April 4-11).  Team Watch:  Rajasthan Royals  Tactics & Matchups: Miller has struggled against both Chahal and Ashwin, falling to them thrice each. If RR's pacers strike early as they have so far in the season, then the spin duo will fancy their chance to break into the middle order early.  Probable XI: Jos Buttler, Yashasvi Jaiswal/Devdutt Padikkal, Sanju Samson (c & wk), Shimron Hetmyer, Riyan Parag, Ravichandran Ashwin, Jimmy Neesham, Navdeep Saini, Trent Boult, Prasidh Krishna, Yuzvendra Chahal  Gujarat Titans  B7$ Rashid Khan will have a big role to play in containing the dangerous Jos Buttler and later in the order, Shimron Hetmyer - both of who have been among the runs this season. Rashid has a good record against the two dismissing them four times, especially with Buttler averaging just 4.50 against the legspinner.  Probable XI: Rahmanullah Gurbaz/Matthew Wade (wk), Shubman Gill, Sai Sudharsan, Hardik Pandya (c), David Miller, Rahul Tewatia, Abhinav Manohar, Rashid Khan, Lockie Ferguson, Mohammed Shami, Darshan Nalkande  Did you know?  - There was seven first innings totals in excess of 170 in the first 11 matches and just two in the ten subsequent matches, both in Brabourne.  - Only Bumrah has taken more wickets than the duo of Rashid Khan and Yuzvendra Chahal in the last half-a-decade in the IPL. And in the middle overs, the two spinners sit on top of the wicket charts.  - Hetmyer has the second-highest strike-rate in death overs since IPL 2019 behind AB de Villiers. He strikes at 195.95 with a boundary percentage of 27.3.  What they said:  "The toss is not in our control. We are learning to adapt our game keeping the dew factor in mind. Both toss and the subsequent dew in the second half of the game is out of our hands," Padikkal said.

team_a_subs: Preview by Kritika Naidu  The overview:  Little separates Rajasthan Royals and the Gujarat Titans after four games in the 2022 edition. They're both tied on 6 points with three wins and a loss. Between both captains, Sanju Samson and Hardik Pandya, they've won just the one toss; RR are yet to chase in the tournament.  But most importantly, both sides' pacers have dominated the powerplay phase this season - with Trent Boult & Prasidh Krishna for RR, Mohammed Shami, Hardik Pandya and Lockie Ferguson for GT. RR's pacers have picked up 8 wickets, averaging 14.25, while GT's have 9 wickets at 17.00. Rashid Khan and Yuzvendra Chahal have been the most successful bowlers in the middle overs since IPL 2017, averaging 20.21 and 20.97 with 70 and 60 wickets respectively.  Gujarat, meanwhile, were handed their first loss of the season after an eight-wicket trouncing at the hands of the Sunrisers Hyderabad. One aspect that has hurt GT has been their opening stand which hasn't survived a powerplay so far. In the four games, their first-wicket stands have been worth: 4, 2, 32 and 24. Left-hander Sai Sudarshan batting at No.3 now provides break in the run of right-handers at the top. Matthew Wade will likely make way for Rahmanullah Gurbaz, considering his inability to get starts so far and factoring in the latter's superior record in Asia. Gurbaz, in 68 innings, has amassed 1620 runs at an average of 24.17, striking at a dangerous 151.82 as opposed to Wade's 93.36. The middle-order too has been needing to get among the runs with David Miller yet to fire.  Samson too has had little success after the first game; it's evident he's struggling when pace is taken off in what has been his slowest start to a season in the last six years. His game has been found wanting on slower tracks in the past, and with tracks set to slow down as the season progress, his form could be a cause of concern for the Royals. Shimron Hetmyer's display of power and skill in the death, though, has done RR a world of good. He's striking at close to 200 and has contributed in all four games so far. Gujarat will want to contain him in the death, with Rashid having the wood over him, but GT may have vital strategic decisions to make as to how Rashid should be used.  When: RR vs GT, April 14, 19:30 IST  Where: Dr DY Patil Sports Academy, NaviMumbai  What to expect: The CSK-RCB game was played on a used wicket, with it being so dry that the dust on it was palpable. The spinners played a crucial role in the second innings with 7 wickets shared between Mahesh Theekshana and Ravindra Jadeja. If a similar wicket is on offer, both sides have the arsenal to use it to their advantage. The average first innings total has come down from 177 in 11 games in the first week (March 26-April 3) to 163 in 10 in the second week (April 4-11).  Team Watch:  Rajasthan Royals  Tactics & Matchups: Miller has struggled against both Chahal and Ashwin, falling to them thrice each. If RR's pacers strike early as they have so far in the season, then the spin duo will fancy their chance to break into the middle order early.  Probable XI: Jos Buttler, Yashasvi Jaiswal/Devdutt Padikkal, Sanju Samson (c & wk), Shimron Hetmyer, Riyan Parag, Ravichandran Ashwin, Jimmy Neesham, Navdeep Saini, Trent Boult, Prasidh Krishna, Yuzvendra Chahal  Gujarat Titans  B7$ Rashid Khan will have a big role to play in containing the dangerous Jos Buttler and later in the order, Shimron Hetmyer - both of who have been among the runs this season. Rashid has a good record against the two dismissing them four times, especially with Buttler averaging just 4.50 against the legspinner.  Probable XI: Rahmanullah Gurbaz/Matthew Wade (wk), Shubman Gill, Sai Sudharsan, Hardik Pandya (c), David Miller, Rahul Tewatia, Abhinav Manohar, Rashid Khan, Lockie Ferguson, Mohammed Shami, Darshan Nalkande  Did you know?  - There was seven first innings totals in excess of 170 in the first 11 matches and just two in the ten subsequent matches, both in Brabourne.  - Only Bumrah has taken more wickets than the duo of Rashid Khan and Yuzvendra Chahal in the last half-a-decade in the IPL. And in the middle overs, the two spinners sit on top of the wicket charts.  - Hetmyer has the second-highest strike-rate in death overs since IPL 2019 behind AB de Villiers. He strikes at 195.95 with a boundary percentage of 27.3.  What they said:  "The toss is not in our control. We are learning to adapt our game keeping the dew factor in mind. Both toss and the subsequent dew in the second half of the game is out of our hands," Padikkal said.

Commentary Text: Shami to Hetmyer, out Caught by Rahul Tewatia!! Was that needed? He already had plenty in the bag for this over. Hetmyer was looking to heave that over long-on but cue-ends this one. The man at long-on runs in and takes an easy catch. Might well be the last nail in the coffin. RR haven't paced the chase well and Hetmyer's dismissal is another example. Hetmyer c Rahul Tewatia b Shami 29(17) [4s-2 6s-1]
team_a_11: Rajasthan Royals (Playing XI): Jos Buttler, Devdutt Padikkal, Sanju Samson(w/c), Rassie van der Dussen, Shimron Hetmyer, James Neesham, Riyan Parag, Ravichandran Ashwin, Kuldeep Sen, Prasidh Krishna, Yuzvendra Chahal

Probable XI: Rahmanullah Gurbaz/Matthew Wade (wk), Shubman Gill, Sai Sudharsan, Hardik Pandya (c), David Miller, Rahul Tewatia, Abhinav Manohar, Rashid Khan, Lockie Ferguson, Mohammed Shami, Darshan Nalkande  Did you know?  - There was seven first innings totals in excess of 170 in the first 11 matches and just two in the ten subsequent matches, both in Brabourne.  - Only Bumrah has taken more wickets than the duo of Rashid Khan and Yuzvendra Chahal in the last half-a-decade in the IPL. And in the middle overs, the two spinners sit on top of the wicket charts.  - Hetmyer has the second-highest strike-rate in death overs since IPL 2019 behind AB de Villiers. He strikes at 195.95 with a boundary percentage of 27.3.  What they said:  "The toss is not in our control. We are learning to adapt our game keeping the dew factor in mind. Commentary Text: Shami to Hetmyer, 2 runs, swings it across the line and gets it little away from deep square for a couple of runs
team_a_11: Rajasthan Royals (Playing XI): Jos Buttler, Devdutt Padikkal, Sanju Samson(w/c), Rassie van der Dussen, Shimron Hetmyer, James Neesham, Riyan Parag, Ravichandran Ashwin, Kuldeep Sen, Prasidh Krishna, Yuzvendra Chahal
team_b_11: Gujarat Titans (Playing XI): Matthew Wade(w), Shubman Gill, Vijay Shankar, Hardik Pandya(c), David Miller, Abhinav Manohar, Rahul Tewatia, Rashid Khan, Lockie Ferguson, Mohammed Shami, Yash Dayal
team_a_subs: Preview by Kritika Naidu  The overview:  Little separates Rajasthan Royals and the Gujarat Titans after four games in the 2022 edition. They're both tied on 6 points with three wins and a loss. Between both captains, Sanju Samson and Hardik Pandya, they've won just the one toss; RR are yet to chase in the tournament.  But most importantly, both sides' pacers have dominated the powerplay phase this season - with Trent Boult & Prasidh Krishna for RR, Mohammed Shami, Hardik Pandya and Lockie Ferguson for GT. RR's pacers have picked up 8 wickets, averaging 14.25, while GT's have 9 wickets at 17.00. Rashid Khan and Yuzvendra Chahal have been the most successful bowlers in the middle overs since IPL 2017, averaging 20.21 and 20.97 with 70 and 60 wickets respectively.  Gujarat, meanwhile, were handed their first loss of the season after an eight-wicket trouncing at the hands of the Sunrisers Hyderabad. One aspect that has hurt GT has been their opening stand which hasn't survived a powerplay so far. In the four games, their first-wicket stands have been worth: 4, 2, 32 and 24. Left-hander Sai Sudarshan batting at No.3 now provides break in the run of right-handers at the top. Matthew Wade will likely make way for Rahmanullah Gurbaz, considering his inability to get starts so far and factoring in the latter's superior record in Asia. Gurbaz, in 68 innings, has amassed 1620 runs at an average of 24.17, striking at a dangerous 151.82 as opposed to Wade's 93.36. The middle-order too has been needing to get among the runs with David Miller yet to fire.  Samson too has had little success after the first game; it's evident he's struggling when pace is taken off in what has been his slowest start to a season in the last six years. His game has been found wanting on slower tracks in the past, and with tracks set to slow down as the season progress, his form could be a cause of concern for the Royals. Shimron Hetmyer's display of power and skill in the death, though, has done RR a world of good. He's striking at close to 200 and has contributed in all four games so far. Gujarat will want to contain him in the death, with Rashid having the wood over him, but GT may have vital strategic decisions to make as to how Rashid should be used.  When: RR vs GT, April 14, 19:30 IST  Where: Dr DY Patil Sports Academy, NaviMumbai  What to expect: The CSK-RCB game was played on a used wicket, with it being so dry that the dust on it was palpable. The spinners played a crucial role in the second innings with 7 wickets shared between Mahesh Theekshana and Ravindra Jadeja. If a similar wicket is on offer, both sides have the arsenal to use it to their advantage. The average first innings total has come down from 177 in 11 games in the first week (March 26-April 3) to 163 in 10 in the second week (April 4-11).  Team Watch:  Rajasthan Royals  Tactics & Matchups: Miller has struggled against both Chahal and Ashwin, falling to them thrice each. If RR's pacers strike early as they have so far in the season, then the spin duo will fancy their chance to break into the middle order early.  Probable XI: Jos Buttler, Yashasvi Jaiswal/Devdutt Padikkal, Sanju Samson (c & wk), Shimron Hetmyer, Riyan Parag, Ravichandran Ashwin, Jimmy Neesham, Navdeep Saini, Trent Boult, Prasidh Krishna, Yuzvendra Chahal  Gujarat Titans  B7$ Rashid Khan will have a big role to play in containing the dangerous Jos Buttler and later in the order, Shimron Hetmyer - both of who have been among the runs this season. Rashid has a good record against the two dismissing them four times, especially with Buttler averaging just 4.50 against the legspinner.  Probable XI: Rahmanullah Gurbaz/Matthew Wade (wk), Shubman Gill, Sai Sudharsan, Hardik Pandya (c), David Miller, Rahul Tewatia, Abhinav Manohar, Rashid Khan, Lockie Ferguson, Mohammed Shami, Darshan Nalkande  Did you know?  - There was seven first innings totals in excess of 170 in the first 11 matches and just two in the ten subsequent matches, both in Brabourne.  - Only Bumrah has taken more wickets than the duo of Rashid Khan and Yuzvendra Chahal in the last half-a-decade in the IPL. And in the middle overs, the two spinners sit on top of the wicket charts.  - Hetmyer has the second-highest strike-rate in death overs since IPL 2019 behind AB de Villiers. He strikes at 195.95 with a boundary percentage of 27.3.  What they said:  "The toss is not in our control. We are learning to adapt our game keeping the dew factor in mind. Both toss and the subsequent dew in the second half of the game is out of our hands," Padikkal said.

Commentary Text: Shami to Hetmyer, FOUR, has HP dropped the catch which will cost them dear? That was a flat-batted slam down the ground and HP at mid-off tipped it over the bar. The ball flew to the fence after bursting through his fingers. Was banged in and Hetmyer slammed it hard. Hardik was seen flinging his fingers in pain. Hope he hasn't been hurt a lot

Commentary Text: Shami to Hetmyer, SIX, and a big hit! Hetmyer on the move. Rajasthan needs more of this. That was banged in from round the wicket and Hetmyer slams the pull over deep mid. That was hit really hard and flat. That will bring down the rate a little

Commentary Text: Shami to Hetmyer, 2 runs, slogs a length delivery and the man at long-on slides to his left to stop that to a couple
team_a_11: Rajasthan Royals (Playing XI): Jos Buttler, Devdutt Padikkal, Sanju Samson(w/c), Rassie van der Dussen, Shimron Hetmyer, James Neesham, Riyan Parag, Ravichandran Ashwin, Kuldeep Sen, Prasidh Krishna, Yuzvendra Chahal
team_b_11: Gujarat Titans (Playing XI): Matthew Wade(w), Shubman Gill, Vijay Shankar, Hardik Pandya(c), David Miller, Abhinav Manohar, Rahul Tewatia, Rashid Khan, Lockie Ferguson, Mohammed Shami, Yash Dayal
team_a_subs: Preview by Kritika Naidu  The overview:  Little separates Rajasthan Royals and the Gujarat Titans after four games in the 2022 edition. They're both tied on 6 points with three wins and a loss. Between both captains, Sanju Samson and Hardik Pandya, they've won just the one toss; RR are yet to chase in the tournament.  But most importantly, both sides' pacers have dominated the powerplay phase this season - with Trent Boult & Prasidh Krishna for RR, Mohammed Shami, Hardik Pandya and Lockie Ferguson for GT. RR's pacers have picked up 8 wickets, averaging 14.25, while GT's have 9 wickets at 17.00. Rashid Khan and Yuzvendra Chahal have been the most successful bowlers in the middle overs since IPL 2017, averaging 20.21 and 20.97 with 70 and 60 wickets respectively.  Gujarat, meanwhile, were handed their first loss of the season after an eight-wicket trouncing at the hands of the Sunrisers Hyderabad. One aspect that has hurt GT has been their opening stand which hasn't survived a powerplay so far. In the four games, their first-wicket stands have been worth: 4, 2, 32 and 24. Left-hander Sai Sudarshan batting at No.3 now provides break in the run of right-handers at the top. Matthew Wade will likely make way for Rahmanullah Gurbaz, considering his inability to get starts so far and factoring in the latter's superior record in Asia. Gurbaz, in 68 innings, has amassed 1620 runs at an average of 24.17, striking at a dangerous 151.82 as opposed to Wade's 93.36. The middle-order too has been needing to get among the runs with David Miller yet to fire.  Samson too has had little success after the first game; it's evident he's struggling when pace is taken off in what has been his slowest start to a season in the last six years. His game has been found wanting on slower tracks in the past, and with tracks set to slow down as the season progress, his form could be a cause of concern for the Royals. Shimron Hetmyer's display of power and skill in the death, though, has done RR a world of good. He's striking at close to 200 and has contributed in all four games so far. Gujarat will want to contain him in the death, with Rashid having the wood over him, but GT may have vital strategic decisions to make as to how Rashid should be used. Gurbaz, in 68 innings, has amassed 1620 runs at an average of 24.17, striking at a dangerous 151.82 as opposed to Wade's 93.36. The middle-order too has been needing to get among the runs with David Miller yet to fire.  Samson too has had little success after the first game; it's evident he's struggling when pace is taken off in what has been his slowest start to a season in the last six years. His game has been found wanting on slower tracks in the past, and with tracks set to slow down as the season progress, his form could be a cause of concern for the Royals. Shimron Hetmyer's display of power and skill in the death, though, has done RR a world of good. He's striking at close to 200 and has contributed in all four games so far. Gujarat will want to contain him in the death, with Rashid having the wood over him, but GT may have vital strategic decisions to make as to how Rashid should be used.  When: RR vs GT, April 14, 19:30 IST  Where: Dr DY Patil Sports Academy, NaviMumbai  What to expect: The CSK-RCB game was played on a used wicket, with it being so dry that the dust on it was palpable. The spinners played a crucial role in the second innings with 7 wickets shared between Mahesh Theekshana and Ravindra Jadeja. If a similar wicket is on offer, both sides have the arsenal to use it to their advantage. The average first innings total has come down from 177 in 11 games in the first week (March 26-April 3) to 163 in 10 in the second week (April 4-11).  Team Watch:  Rajasthan Royals  Tactics & Matchups: Miller has struggled against both Chahal and Ashwin, falling to them thrice each. If RR's pacers strike early as they have so far in the season, then the spin duo will fancy their chance to break into the middle order early.  Probable XI: Jos Buttler, Yashasvi Jaiswal/Devdutt Padikkal, Sanju Samson (c & wk), Shimron Hetmyer, Riyan Parag, Ravichandran Ashwin, Jimmy Neesham, Navdeep Saini, Trent Boult, Prasidh Krishna, Yuzvendra Chahal  Gujarat Titans  B7$ Rashid Khan will have a big role to play in containing the dangerous Jos Buttler and later in the order, Shimron Hetmyer - both of who have been among the runs this season. Rashid has a good record against the two dismissing them four times, especially with Buttler averaging just 4.50 against the legspinner.  Probable XI: Rahmanullah Gurbaz/Matthew Wade (wk), Shubman Gill, Sai Sudharsan, Hardik Pandya (c), David Miller, Rahul Tewatia, Abhinav Manohar, Rashid Khan, Lockie Ferguson, Mohammed Shami, Darshan Nalkande  Did you know?  - There was seven first innings totals in excess of 170 in the first 11 matches and just two in the ten subsequent matches, both in Brabourne.  - Only Bumrah has taken more wickets than the duo of Rashid Khan and Yuzvendra Chahal in the last half-a-decade in the IPL. And in the middle overs, the two spinners sit on top of the wicket charts.  - Hetmyer has the second-highest strike-rate in death overs since IPL 2019 behind AB de Villiers. He strikes at 195.95 with a boundary percentage of 27.3.  What they said:  "The toss is not in our control. We are learning to adapt our game keeping the dew factor in mind. Both toss and the subsequent dew in the second half of the game is out of our hands," Padikkal said.
toss: Rajasthan Royals have won the toss and have opted to field

Commentary Text: Hardik Pandya to Hetmyer, FOUR, and a welcome four! Hetmyer and RR will take it. Took on the short ball and placed it really wel between deep mid and deep square. Hetmyer needs to kick on and score big if this has to go the distance
team_a_11: Rajasthan Royals (Playing XI): Jos Buttler, Devdutt Padikkal, Sanju Samson(w/c), Rassie van der Dussen, Shimron Hetmyer, James Neesham, Riyan Parag, Ravichandran Ashwin, Kuldeep Sen, Prasidh Krishna, Yuzvendra Chahal
team_b_11: Gujarat Titans (Playing XI): Matthew Wade(w), Shubman Gill, Vijay Shankar, Hardik Pandya(c), David Miller, Abhinav Manohar, Rahul Tewatia, Rashid Khan, Lockie Ferguson, Mohammed Shami, Yash Dayal
team_a_subs: Preview by Kritika Naidu  The overview:  Little separates Rajasthan Royals and the Gujarat Titans after four games in the 2022 edition. They're both tied on 6 points with three wins and a loss. Between both captains, Sanju Samson and Hardik Pandya, they've won just the one toss; RR are yet to chase in the tournament.  But most importantly, both sides' pacers have dominated the powerplay phase this season - with Trent Boult & Prasidh Krishna for RR, Mohammed Shami, Hardik Pandya and Lockie Ferguson for GT. RR's pacers have picked up 8 wickets, averaging 14.25, while GT's have 9 wickets at 17.00. Rashid Khan and Yuzvendra Chahal have been the most successful bowlers in the middle overs since IPL 2017, averaging 20.21 and 20.97 with 70 and 60 wickets respectively.  Gujarat, meanwhile, were handed their first loss of the season after an eight-wicket trouncing at the hands of the Sunrisers Hyderabad. One aspect that has hurt GT has been their opening stand which hasn't survived a powerplay so far. In the four games, their first-wicket stands have been worth: 4, 2, 32 and 24. Left-hander Sai Sudarshan batting at No.3 now provides break in the run of right-handers at the top. Matthew Wade will likely make way for Rahmanullah Gurbaz, considering his inability to get starts so far and factoring in the latter's superior record in Asia. Gurbaz, in 68 innings, has amassed 1620 runs at an average of 24.17, striking at a dangerous 151.82 as opposed to Wade's 93.36. The middle-order too has been needing to get among the runs with David Miller yet to fire.  Samson too has had little success after the first game; it's evident he's struggling when pace is taken off in what has been his slowest start to a season in the last six years. His game has been found wanting on slower tracks in the past, and with tracks set to slow down as the season progress, his form could be a cause of concern for the Royals. Shimron Hetmyer's display of power and skill in the death, though, has done RR a world of good. He's striking at close to 200 and has contributed in all four games so far. Gujarat will want to contain him in the death, with Rashid having the wood over him, but GT may have vital strategic decisions to make as to how Rashid should be used. They're both tied on 6 points with three wins and a loss. Between both captains, Sanju Samson and Hardik Pandya, they've won just the one toss; RR are yet to chase in the tournament.  But most importantly, both sides' pacers have dominated the powerplay phase this season - with Trent Boult & Prasidh Krishna for RR, Mohammed Shami, Hardik Pandya and Lockie Ferguson for GT. RR's pacers have picked up 8 wickets, averaging 14.25, while GT's have 9 wickets at 17.00. Rashid Khan and Yuzvendra Chahal have been the most successful bowlers in the middle overs since IPL 2017, averaging 20.21 and 20.97 with 70 and 60 wickets respectively.  Gujarat, meanwhile, were handed their first loss of the season after an eight-wicket trouncing at the hands of the Sunrisers Hyderabad. One aspect that has hurt GT has been their opening stand which hasn't survived a powerplay so far. In the four games, their first-wicket stands have been worth: 4, 2, 32 and 24. Left-hander Sai Sudarshan batting at No.3 now provides break in the run of right-handers at the top. Matthew Wade will likely make way for Rahmanullah Gurbaz, considering his inability to get starts so far and factoring in the latter's superior record in Asia. Gurbaz, in 68 innings, has amassed 1620 runs at an average of 24.17, striking at a dangerous 151.82 as opposed to Wade's 93.36. The middle-order too has been needing to get among the runs with David Miller yet to fire.  Samson too has had little success after the first game; it's evident he's struggling when pace is taken off in what has been his slowest start to a season in the last six years. His game has been found wanting on slower tracks in the past, and with tracks set to slow down as the season progress, his form could be a cause of concern for the Royals. Shimron Hetmyer's display of power and skill in the death, though, has done RR a world of good. He's striking at close to 200 and has contributed in all four games so far. Gujarat will want to contain him in the death, with Rashid having the wood over him, but GT may have vital strategic decisions to make as to how Rashid should be used.  When: RR vs GT, April 14, 19:30 IST  Where: Dr DY Patil Sports Academy, NaviMumbai  What to expect: The CSK-RCB game was played on a used wicket, with it being so dry that the dust on it was palpable. The spinners played a crucial role in the second innings with 7 wickets shared between Mahesh Theekshana and Ravindra Jadeja. If a similar wicket is on offer, both sides have the arsenal to use it to their advantage. The average first innings total has come down from 177 in 11 games in the first week (March 26-April 3) to 163 in 10 in the second week (April 4-11).  Team Watch:  Rajasthan Royals  Tactics & Matchups: Miller has struggled against both Chahal and Ashwin, falling to them thrice each. If RR's pacers strike early as they have so far in the season, then the spin duo will fancy their chance to break into the middle order early.  Probable XI: Jos Buttler, Yashasvi Jaiswal/Devdutt Padikkal, Sanju Samson (c & wk), Shimron Hetmyer, Riyan Parag, Ravichandran Ashwin, Jimmy Neesham, Navdeep Saini, Trent Boult, Prasidh Krishna, Yuzvendra Chahal  Gujarat Titans  B7$ Rashid Khan will have a big role to play in containing the dangerous Jos Buttler and later in the order, Shimron Hetmyer - both of who have been among the runs this season. Rashid has a good record against the two dismissing them four times, especially with Buttler averaging just 4.50 against the legspinner.  Probable XI: Rahmanullah Gurbaz/Matthew Wade (wk), Shubman Gill, Sai Sudharsan, Hardik Pandya (c), David Miller, Rahul Tewatia, Abhinav Manohar, Rashid Khan, Lockie Ferguson, Mohammed Shami, Darshan Nalkande  Did you know?  - There was seven first innings totals in excess of 170 in the first 11 matches and just two in the ten subsequent matches, both in Brabourne.  - Only Bumrah has taken more wickets than the duo of Rashid Khan and Yuzvendra Chahal in the last half-a-decade in the IPL. And in the middle overs, the two spinners sit on top of the wicket charts.  - Hetmyer has the second-highest strike-rate in death overs since IPL 2019 behind AB de Villiers. He strikes at 195.95 with a boundary percentage of 27.3.  What they said:  "The toss is not in our control. We are learning to adapt our game keeping the dew factor in mind. Both toss and the subsequent dew in the second half of the game is out of our hands," Padikkal said.
toss: Rajasthan Royals have won the toss and have opted to field

Commentary Text: Hardik Pandya to Riyan Parag, no run, back of a length delivery, angling in and has been turned away to the man at mid-wicket with soft hands

Probable XI: Rahmanullah Gurbaz/Matthew Wade (wk), Shubman Gill, Sai Sudharsan, Hardik Pandya (c), David Miller, Rahul Tewatia, Abhinav Manohar, Rashid Khan, Lockie Ferguson, Mohammed Shami, Darshan Nalkande  Did you know?  - There was seven first innings totals in excess of 170 in the first 11 matches and just two in the ten subsequent matches, both in Brabourne.  - Only Bumrah has taken more wickets than the duo of Rashid Khan and Yuzvendra Chahal in the last half-a-decade in the IPL. And in the middle overs, the two spinners sit on top of the wicket charts.  - Hetmyer has the second-highest strike-rate in death overs since IPL 2019 behind AB de Villiers. He strikes at 195.95 with a boundary percentage of 27.3.  What they said:  "The toss is not in our control. We are learning to adapt our game keeping the dew factor in mind. Both toss and the subsequent dew in the second half of the game is out of our hands," Padikkal said.
team_b_subs: Preview by Kritika Naidu  The overview:  Little separates Rajasthan Royals and the Gujarat Titans after four games in the 2022 edition. They're both tied on 6 points with three wins and a loss. Between both captains, Sanju Samson and Hardik Pandya, they've won just the one toss; RR are yet to chase in the tournament.  But most importantly, both sides' pacers have dominated the powerplay phase this season - with Trent Boult & Prasidh Krishna for RR, Mohammed Shami, Hardik Pandya and Lockie Ferguson for GT. RR's pacers have picked up 8 wickets, averaging 14.25, while GT's have 9 wickets at 17.00. Rashid Khan and Yuzvendra Chahal have been the most successful bowlers in the middle overs since IPL 2017, averaging 20.21 and 20.97 with 70 and 60 wickets respectively.  Gujarat, meanwhile, were handed their first loss of the season after an eight-wicket trouncing at the hands of the Sunrisers Hyderabad. One aspect that has hurt GT has been their opening stand which hasn't survived a powerplay so far. In the four games, their first-wicket stands have been worth: 4, 2, 32 and 24. Left-hander Sai Sudarshan batting at No.3 now provides break in the run of right-handers at the top. Matthew Wade will likely make way for Rahmanullah Gurbaz, considering his inability to get starts so far and factoring in the latter's superior record in Asia. Gurbaz, in 68 innings, has amassed 1620 runs at an average of 24.17, striking at a dangerous 151.82 as opposed to Wade's 93.36. The middle-order too has been needing to get among the runs with David Miller yet to fire.  Samson too has had little success after the first game; it's evident he's struggling when pace is taken off in what has been his slowest start to a season in the last six years. His game has been found wanting on slower tracks in the past, and with tracks set to slow down as the season progress, his form could be a cause of concern for the Royals. Shimron Hetmyer's display of power and skill in the death, though, has done RR a world of good. He's striking at close to 200 and has contributed in all four games so far. Gujarat will want to contain him in the death, with Rashid having the wood over him, but GT may have vital strategic decisions to make as to how Rashid should be used.  When: RR vs GT, April 14, 19:30 IST  Where: Dr DY Patil Sports Academy, NaviMumbai  What to expect: The CSK-RCB game was played on a used wicket, with it being so dry that the dust on it was palpable. The spinners played a crucial role in the second innings with 7 wickets shared between Mahesh Theekshana and Ravindra Jadeja. If a similar wicket is on offer, both sides have the arsenal to use it to their advantage. The average first innings total has come down from 177 in 11 games in the first week (March 26-April 3) to 163 in 10 in the second week (April 4-11).  Team Watch:  Rajasthan Royals  Tactics & Matchups: Miller has struggled against both Chahal and Ashwin, falling to them thrice each. If RR's pacers strike early as they have so far in the season, then the spin duo will fancy their chance to break into the middle order early.  Probable XI: Jos Buttler, Yashasvi Jaiswal/Devdutt Padikkal, Sanju Samson (c & wk), Shimron Hetmyer, Riyan Parag, Ravichandran Ashwin, Jimmy Neesham, Navdeep Saini, Trent Boult, Prasidh Krishna, Yuzvendra Chahal  Gujarat Titans  B7$ Rashid Khan will have a big role to play in containing the dangerous Jos Buttler and later in the order, Shimron Hetmyer - both of who have been among the runs this season. Commentary Text: Yash Dayal to van der Dussen, out Caught by Wade!! That is a superb away angler and induces the edge. The batter looks to drive and gets an outside edge for the keeper to do the rest. Rajasthan are imploding. That was a lovely delivery and nipped away to take the edge. van der Dussen is a gutted man. Half the side is back in the hut. van der Dussen c Wade b Yash Dayal 6(10)

The spinners played a crucial role in the second innings with 7 wickets shared between Mahesh Theekshana and Ravindra Jadeja. If a similar wicket is on offer, both sides have the arsenal to use it to their advantage. The average first innings total has come down from 177 in 11 games in the first week (March 26-April 3) to 163 in 10 in the second week (April 4-11).  Team Watch:  Rajasthan Royals  Tactics & Matchups: Miller has struggled against both Chahal and Ashwin, falling to them thrice each. Gurbaz, in 68 innings, has amassed 1620 runs at an average of 24.17, striking at a dangerous 151.82 as opposed to Wade's 93.36. The middle-order too has been needing to get among the runs with David Miller yet to fire.  Samson too has had little success after the first game; it's evident he's struggling when pace is taken off in what has been his slowest start to a season in the last six years. His game has been found wanting on slower tracks in the past, and with tracks set to slow down as the season progress, his form could be a cause of concern for the Royals. Shimron Hetmyer's display of power and skill in the death, though, has done RR a world of good. He's striking at close to 200 and has contributed in all four games so far. Gujarat will want to contain him in the death, with Rashid having the wood over him, but GT may have vital strategic decisions to make as to how Rashid should be used.  When: RR vs GT, April 14, 19:30 IST  Where: Dr DY Patil Sports Academy, NaviMumbai  What to expect: The CSK-RCB game was played on a used wicket, with it being so dry that the dust on it was palpable. The spinners played a crucial role in the second innings with 7 wickets shared between Mahesh Theekshana and Ravindra Jadeja. If a similar wicket is on offer, both sides have the arsenal to use it to their advantage. The average first innings total has come down from 177 in 11 games in the first week (March 26-April 3) to 163 in 10 in the second week (April 4-11).  Team Watch:  Rajasthan Royals  Tactics & Matchups: Miller has struggled against both Chahal and Ashwin, falling to them thrice each. If RR's pacers strike early as they have so far in the season, then the spin duo will fancy their chance to break into the middle order early.  Probable XI: Jos Buttler, Yashasvi Jaiswal/Devdutt Padikkal, Sanju Samson (c & wk), Shimron Hetmyer, Riyan Parag, Ravichandran Ashwin, Jimmy Neesham, Navdeep Saini, Trent Boult, Prasidh Krishna, Yuzvendra Chahal  Gujarat Titans  B7$ Rashid Khan will have a big role to play in containing the dangerous Jos Buttler and later in the order, Shimron Hetmyer - both of who have been among the runs this season. Rashid has a good record against the two dismissing them four times, especially with Buttler averaging just 4.50 against the legspinner.  Probable XI: Rahmanullah Gurbaz/Matthew Wade (wk), Shubman Gill, Sai Sudharsan, Hardik Pandya (c), David Miller, Rahul Tewatia, Abhinav Manohar, Rashid Khan, Lockie Ferguson, Mohammed Shami, Darshan Nalkande  Did you know?  - There was seven first innings totals in excess of 170 in the first 11 matches and just two in the ten subsequent matches, both in Brabourne.  - Only Bumrah has taken more wickets than the duo of Rashid Khan and Yuzvendra Chahal in the last half-a-decade in the IPL. And in the middle overs, the two spinners sit on top of the wicket charts.  - Hetmyer has the second-highest strike-rate in death overs since IPL 2019 behind AB de Villiers. He strikes at 195.95 with a boundary percentage of 27.3.  What they said:  "The toss is not in our control. We are learning to adapt our game keeping the dew factor in mind. Both toss and the subsequent dew in the second half of the game is out of our hands," Padikkal said.

Rashid Khan and Yuzvendra Chahal have been the most successful bowlers in the middle overs since IPL 2017, averaging 20.21 and 20.97 with 70 and 60 wickets respectively.  Gujarat, meanwhile, were handed their first loss of the season after an eight-wicket trouncing at the hands of the Sunrisers Hyderabad. One aspect that has hurt GT has been their opening stand which hasn't survived a powerplay so far. In the four games, their first-wicket stands have been worth: 4, 2, 32 and 24. Left-hander Sai Sudarshan batting at No.3 now provides break in the run of right-handers at the top. Matthew Wade will likely make way for Rahmanullah Gurbaz, considering his inability to get starts so far and factoring in the latter's superior record in Asia. Gurbaz, in 68 innings, has amassed 1620 runs at an average of 24.17, striking at a dangerous 151.82 as opposed to Wade's 93.36. The middle-order too has been needing to get among the runs with David Miller yet to fire.  Samson too has had little success after the first game; it's evident he's struggling when pace is taken off in what has been his slowest start to a season in the last six years. His game has been found wanting on slower tracks in the past, and with tracks set to slow down as the season progress, his form could be a cause of concern for the Royals. Shimron Hetmyer's display of power and skill in the death, though, has done RR a world of good. He's striking at close to 200 and has contributed in all four games so far. Gujarat will want to contain him in the death, with Rashid having the wood over him, but GT may have vital strategic decisions to make as to how Rashid should be used.  When: RR vs GT, April 14, 19:30 IST  Where: Dr DY Patil Sports Academy, NaviMumbai  What to expect: The CSK-RCB game was played on a used wicket, with it being so dry that the dust on it was palpable. The spinners played a crucial role in the second innings with 7 wickets shared between Mahesh Theekshana and Ravindra Jadeja. If a similar wicket is on offer, both sides have the arsenal to use it to their advantage. The average first innings total has come down from 177 in 11 games in the first week (March 26-April 3) to 163 in 10 in the second week (April 4-11).  Team Watch:  Rajasthan Royals  Tactics & Matchups: Miller has struggled against both Chahal and Ashwin, falling to them thrice each. If RR's pacers strike early as they have so far in the season, then the spin duo will fancy their chance to break into the middle order early.  Probable XI: Jos Buttler, Yashasvi Jaiswal/Devdutt Padikkal, Sanju Samson (c & wk), Shimron Hetmyer, Riyan Parag, Ravichandran Ashwin, Jimmy Neesham, Navdeep Saini, Trent Boult, Prasidh Krishna, Yuzvendra Chahal  Gujarat Titans  B7$ Rashid Khan will have a big role to play in containing the dangerous Jos Buttler and later in the order, Shimron Hetmyer - both of who have been among the runs this season. Rashid has a good record against the two dismissing them four times, especially with Buttler averaging just 4.50 against the legspinner.  Probable XI: Rahmanullah Gurbaz/Matthew Wade (wk), Shubman Gill, Sai Sudharsan, Hardik Pandya (c), David Miller, Rahul Tewatia, Abhinav Manohar, Rashid Khan, Lockie Ferguson, Mohammed Shami, Darshan Nalkande  Did you know?  - There was seven first innings totals in excess of 170 in the first 11 matches and just two in the ten subsequent matches, both in Brabourne.  - Only Bumrah has taken more wickets than the duo of Rashid Khan and Yuzvendra Chahal in the last half-a-decade in the IPL. And in the middle overs, the two spinners sit on top of the wicket charts.  - Hetmyer has the second-highest strike-rate in death overs since IPL 2019 behind AB de Villiers. He strikes at 195.95 with a boundary percentage of 27.3.  What they said:  "The toss is not in our control. We are learning to adapt our game keeping the dew factor in mind. Both toss and the subsequent dew in the second half of the game is out of our hands," Padikkal said.

Commentary Text: Hardik Pandya to van der Dussen, 1 run, 137.2kph, starts with a skiddy short ball, pulled to deep square leg
team_a_11: Rajasthan Royals (Playing XI): Jos Buttler, Devdutt Padikkal, Sanju Samson(w/c), Rassie van der Dussen, Shimron Hetmyer, James Neesham, Riyan Parag, Ravichandran Ashwin, Kuldeep Sen, Prasidh Krishna, Yuzvendra Chahal
team_b_11: Gujarat Titans (Playing XI): Matthew Wade(w), Shubman Gill, Vijay Shankar, Hardik Pandya(c), David Miller, Abhinav Manohar, Rahul Tewatia, Rashid Khan, Lockie Ferguson, Mohammed Shami, Yash Dayal
team_a_subs: Preview by Kritika Naidu  The overview:  Little separates Rajasthan Royals and the Gujarat Titans after four games in the 2022 edition. They're both tied on 6 points with three wins and a loss. Between both captains, Sanju Samson and Hardik Pandya, they've won just the one toss; RR are yet to chase in the tournament.  But most importantly, both sides' pacers have dominated the powerplay phase this season - with Trent Boult & Prasidh Krishna for RR, Mohammed Shami, Hardik Pandya and Lockie Ferguson for GT. RR's pacers have picked up 8 wickets, averaging 14.25, while GT's have 9 wickets at 17.00. Rashid Khan and Yuzvendra Chahal have been the most successful bowlers in the middle overs since IPL 2017, averaging 20.21 and 20.97 with 70 and 60 wickets respectively.  Gujarat, meanwhile, were handed their first loss of the season after an eight-wicket trouncing at the hands of the Sunrisers Hyderabad. One aspect that has hurt GT has been their opening stand which hasn't survived a powerplay so far. In the four games, their first-wicket stands have been worth: 4, 2, 32 and 24. Left-hander Sai Sudarshan batting at No.3 now provides break in the run of right-handers at the top. Matthew Wade will likely make way for Rahmanullah Gurbaz, considering his inability to get starts so far and factoring in the latter's superior record in Asia. Gurbaz, in 68 innings, has amassed 1620 runs at an average of 24.17, striking at a dangerous 151.82 as opposed to Wade's 93.36. The middle-order too has been needing to get among the runs with David Miller yet to fire.  Samson too has had little success after the first game; it's evident he's struggling when pace is taken off in what has been his slowest start to a season in the last six years. His game has been found wanting on slower tracks in the past, and with tracks set to slow down as the season progress, his form could be a cause of concern for the Royals. Shimron Hetmyer's display of power and skill in the death, though, has done RR a world of good. He's striking at close to 200 and has contributed in all four games so far. Gujarat will want to contain him in the death, with Rashid having the wood over him, but GT may have vital strategic decisions to make as to how Rashid should be used.  When: RR vs GT, April 14, 19:30 IST  Where: Dr DY Patil Sports Academy, NaviMumbai  What to expect: The CSK-RCB game was played on a used wicket, with it being so dry that the dust on it was palpable. The spinners played a crucial role in the second innings with 7 wickets shared between Mahesh Theekshana and Ravindra Jadeja. If a similar wicket is on offer, both sides have the arsenal to use it to their advantage. The average first innings total has come down from 177 in 11 games in the first week (March 26-April 3) to 163 in 10 in the second week (April 4-11).  Team Watch:  Rajasthan Royals  Tactics & Matchups: Miller has struggled against both Chahal and Ashwin, falling to them thrice each. If RR's pacers strike early as they have so far in the season, then the spin duo will fancy their chance to break into the middle order early.  Probable XI: Jos Buttler, Yashasvi Jaiswal/Devdutt Padikkal, Sanju Samson (c & wk), Shimron Hetmyer, Riyan Parag, Ravichandran Ashwin, Jimmy Neesham, Navdeep Saini, Trent Boult, Prasidh Krishna, Yuzvendra Chahal  Gujarat Titans  B7$ Rashid Khan will have a big role to play in containing the dangerous Jos Buttler and later in the order, Shimron Hetmyer - both of who have been among the runs this season. Rashid has a good record against the two dismissing them four times, especially with Buttler averaging just 4.50 against the legspinner.  Probable XI: Rahmanullah Gurbaz/Matthew Wade (wk), Shubman Gill, Sai Sudharsan, Hardik Pandya (c), David Miller, Rahul Tewatia, Abhinav Manohar, Rashid Khan, Lockie Ferguson, Mohammed Shami, Darshan Nalkande  Did you know?  - There was seven first innings totals in excess of 170 in the first 11 matches and just two in the ten subsequent matches, both in Brabourne.  - Only Bumrah has taken more wickets than the duo of Rashid Khan and Yuzvendra Chahal in the last half-a-decade in the IPL. And in the middle overs, the two spinners sit on top of the wicket charts.  - Hetmyer has the second-highest strike-rate in death overs since IPL 2019 behind AB de Villiers. He strikes at 195.95 with a boundary percentage of 27.3.  What they said:  "The toss is not in our control. We are learning to adapt our game keeping the dew factor in mind. Both toss and the subsequent dew in the second half of the game is out of our hands," Padikkal said.

toss: Rajasthan Royals have won the toss and have opted to field

Commentary Text: Rashid Khan to Hetmyer, 2 runs, 98.4kph, leg-lined, tickled down to fine leg for a brace
team_a_11: Rajasthan Royals (Playing XI): Jos Buttler, Devdutt Padikkal, Sanju Samson(w/c), Rassie van der Dussen, Shimron Hetmyer, James Neesham, Riyan Parag, Ravichandran Ashwin, Kuldeep Sen, Prasidh Krishna, Yuzvendra Chahal

And in the middle overs, the two spinners sit on top of the wicket charts.  - Hetmyer has the second-highest strike-rate in death overs since IPL 2019 behind AB de Villiers. He strikes at 195.95 with a boundary percentage of 27.3.  What they said:  "The toss is not in our control. We are learning to adapt our game keeping the dew factor in mind. Commentary Text: Rashid Khan to van der Dussen, leg byes, 1 run, 93.8kph, googly, spinning down leg, a shuffling van der Dussen misses the flick. Brushes the thigh pad and deflects towards square leg off the keeper's pad
team_a_11: Rajasthan Royals (Playing XI): Jos Buttler, Devdutt Padikkal, Sanju Samson(w/c), Rassie van der Dussen, Shimron Hetmyer, James Neesham, Riyan Parag, Ravichandran Ashwin, Kuldeep Sen, Prasidh Krishna, Yuzvendra Chahal
team_b_11: Gujarat Titans (Playing XI): Matthew Wade(w), Shubman Gill, Vijay Shankar, Hardik Pandya(c), David Miller, Abhinav Manohar, Rahul Tewatia, Rashid Khan, Lockie Ferguson, Mohammed Shami, Yash Dayal
team_a_subs: Preview by Kritika Naidu  The overview:  Little separates Rajasthan Royals and the Gujarat Titans after four games in the 2022 edition. They're both tied on 6 points with three wins and a loss. Between both captains, Sanju Samson and Hardik Pandya, they've won just the one toss; RR are yet to chase in the tournament.  But most importantly, both sides' pacers have dominated the powerplay phase this season - with Trent Boult & Prasidh Krishna for RR, Mohammed Shami, Hardik Pandya and Lockie Ferguson for GT. RR's pacers have picked up 8 wickets, averaging 14.25, while GT's have 9 wickets at 17.00. Rashid Khan and Yuzvendra Chahal have been the most successful bowlers in the middle overs since IPL 2017, averaging 20.21 and 20.97 with 70 and 60 wickets respectively.  Gujarat, meanwhile, were handed their first loss of the season after an eight-wicket trouncing at the hands of the Sunrisers Hyderabad. One aspect that has hurt GT has been their opening stand which hasn't survived a powerplay so far. In the four games, their first-wicket stands have been worth: 4, 2, 32 and 24. Left-hander Sai Sudarshan batting at No.3 now provides break in the run of right-handers at the top. Matthew Wade will likely make way for Rahmanullah Gurbaz, considering his inability to get starts so far and factoring in the latter's superior record in Asia. Gurbaz, in 68 innings, has amassed 1620 runs at an average of 24.17, striking at a dangerous 151.82 as opposed to Wade's 93.36. The middle-order too has been needing to get among the runs with David Miller yet to fire.  Samson too has had little success after the first game; it's evident he's struggling when pace is taken off in what has been his slowest start to a season in the last six years. His game has been found wanting on slower tracks in the past, and with tracks set to slow down as the season progress, his form could be a cause of concern for the Royals. Shimron Hetmyer's display of power and skill in the death, though, has done RR a world of good. He's striking at close to 200 and has contributed in all four games so far. Gujarat will want to contain him in the death, with Rashid having the wood over him, but GT may have vital strategic decisions to make as to how Rashid should be used.  When: RR vs GT, April 14, 19:30 IST  Where: Dr DY Patil Sports Academy, NaviMumbai  What to expect: The CSK-RCB game was played on a used wicket, with it being so dry that the dust on it was palpable. The spinners played a crucial role in the second innings with 7 wickets shared between Mahesh Theekshana and Ravindra Jadeja. If a similar wicket is on offer, both sides have the arsenal to use it to their advantage. The average first innings total has come down from 177 in 11 games in the first week (March 26-April 3) to 163 in 10 in the second week (April 4-11).  Team Watch:  Rajasthan Royals  Tactics & Matchups: Miller has struggled against both Chahal and Ashwin, falling to them thrice each. If RR's pacers strike early as they have so far in the season, then the spin duo will fancy their chance to break into the middle order early.  Probable XI: Jos Buttler, Yashasvi Jaiswal/Devdutt Padikkal, Sanju Samson (c & wk), Shimron Hetmyer, Riyan Parag, Ravichandran Ashwin, Jimmy Neesham, Navdeep Saini, Trent Boult, Prasidh Krishna, Yuzvendra Chahal  Gujarat Titans  B7$ Rashid Khan will have a big role to play in containing the dangerous Jos Buttler and later in the order, Shimron Hetmyer - both of who have been among the runs this season. Both toss and the subsequent dew in the second half of the game is out of our hands," Padikkal said.

Commentary Text: Rashid Khan to Hetmyer, 3 runs, 95.3kph, stabbed to deep extra cover. Hetmyer decides to come back for the third. Rashid tries to flick the throw onto the sticks and misses the target. Hetmyer over-runs and hence the batters can't take the fourth

Commentary Text: Rashid Khan to Hetmyer, no run, 93.8kph, googly wide of off, jabbed to mid-wicket off the back foot
team_a_11: Rajasthan Royals (Playing XI): Jos Buttler, Devdutt Padikkal, Sanju Samson(w/c), Rassie van der Dussen, Shimron Hetmyer, James Neesham, Riyan Parag, Ravichandran Ashwin, Kuldeep Sen, Prasidh Krishna, Yuzvendra Chahal
team_b_11: Gujarat Titans (Playing XI): Matthew Wade(w), Shubman Gill, Vijay Shankar, Hardik Pandya(c), David Miller, Abhinav Manohar, Rahul Tewatia, Rashid Khan, Lockie Ferguson, Mohammed Shami, Yash Dayal
team_a_subs: Preview by Kritika Naidu  The overview:  Little separates Rajasthan Royals and the Gujarat Titans after four games in the 2022 edition. They're both tied on 6 points with three wins and a loss. Between both captains, Sanju Samson and Hardik Pandya, they've won just the one toss; RR are yet to chase in the tournament.  But most importantly, both sides' pacers have dominated the powerplay phase this season - with Trent Boult & Prasidh Krishna for RR, Mohammed Shami, Hardik Pandya and Lockie Ferguson for GT. RR's pacers have picked up 8 wickets, averaging 14.25, while GT's have 9 wickets at 17.00. Rashid Khan and Yuzvendra Chahal have been the most successful bowlers in the middle overs since IPL 2017, averaging 20.21 and 20.97 with 70 and 60 wickets respectively.  Gujarat, meanwhile, were handed their first loss of the season after an eight-wicket trouncing at the hands of the Sunrisers Hyderabad. One aspect that has hurt GT has been their opening stand which hasn't survived a powerplay so far. In the four games, their first-wicket stands have been worth: 4, 2, 32 and 24. Left-hander Sai Sudarshan batting at No.3 now provides break in the run of right-handers at the top. Matthew Wade will likely make way for Rahmanullah Gurbaz, considering his inability to get starts so far and factoring in the latter's superior record in Asia. Gurbaz, in 68 innings, has amassed 1620 runs at an average of 24.17, striking at a dangerous 151.82 as opposed to Wade's 93.36. The middle-order too has been needing to get among the runs with David Miller yet to fire.  Samson too has had little success after the first game; it's evident he's struggling when pace is taken off in what has been his slowest start to a season in the last six years. His game has been found wanting on slower tracks in the past, and with tracks set to slow down as the season progress, his form could be a cause of concern for the Royals. Shimron Hetmyer's display of power and skill in the death, though, has done RR a world of good. He's striking at close to 200 and has contributed in all four games so far. Gujarat will want to contain him in the death, with Rashid having the wood over him, but GT may have vital strategic decisions to make as to how Rashid should be used.  When: RR vs GT, April 14, 19:30 IST  Where: Dr DY Patil Sports Academy, NaviMumbai  What to expect: The CSK-RCB game was played on a used wicket, with it being so dry that the dust on it was palpable. The spinners played a crucial role in the second innings with 7 wickets shared between Mahesh Theekshana and Ravindra Jadeja. If a similar wicket is on offer, both sides have the arsenal to use it to their advantage. The average first innings total has come down from 177 in 11 games in the first week (March 26-April 3) to 163 in 10 in the second week (April 4-11). Gujarat will want to contain him in the death, with Rashid having the wood over him, but GT may have vital strategic decisions to make as to how Rashid should be used. Commentary Text: Ferguson to van der Dussen, no run, 146kph, full on middle, clipped straight to mid-wicket
team_a_11: Rajasthan Royals (Playing XI): Jos Buttler, Devdutt Padikkal, Sanju Samson(w/c), Rassie van der Dussen, Shimron Hetmyer, James Neesham, Riyan Parag, Ravichandran Ashwin, Kuldeep Sen, Prasidh Krishna, Yuzvendra Chahal
team_b_11: Gujarat Titans (Playing XI): Matthew Wade(w), Shubman Gill, Vijay Shankar, Hardik Pandya(c), David Miller, Abhinav Manohar, Rahul Tewatia, Rashid Khan, Lockie Ferguson, Mohammed Shami, Yash Dayal
team_a_subs: Preview by Kritika Naidu  The overview:  Little separates Rajasthan Royals and the Gujarat Titans after four games in the 2022 edition. They're both tied on 6 points with three wins and a loss. Between both captains, Sanju Samson and Hardik Pandya, they've won just the one toss; RR are yet to chase in the tournament.  But most importantly, both sides' pacers have dominated the powerplay phase this season - with Trent Boult & Prasidh Krishna for RR, Mohammed Shami, Hardik Pandya and Lockie Ferguson for GT. RR's pacers have picked up 8 wickets, averaging 14.25, while GT's have 9 wickets at 17.00. Rashid Khan and Yuzvendra Chahal have been the most successful bowlers in the middle overs since IPL 2017, averaging 20.21 and 20.97 with 70 and 60 wickets respectively.  Gujarat, meanwhile, were handed their first loss of the season after an eight-wicket trouncing at the hands of the Sunrisers Hyderabad. One aspect that has hurt GT has been their opening stand which hasn't survived a powerplay so far. In the four games, their first-wicket stands have been worth: 4, 2, 32 and 24. Left-hander Sai Sudarshan batting at No.3 now provides break in the run of right-handers at the top. Matthew Wade will likely make way for Rahmanullah Gurbaz, considering his inability to get starts so far and factoring in the latter's superior record in Asia. Gurbaz, in 68 innings, has amassed 1620 runs at an average of 24.17, striking at a dangerous 151.82 as opposed to Wade's 93.36. The middle-order too has been needing to get among the runs with David Miller yet to fire.  Samson too has had little success after the first game; it's evident he's struggling when pace is taken off in what has been his slowest start to a season in the last six years. His game has been found wanting on slower tracks in the past, and with tracks set to slow down as the season progress, his form could be a cause of concern for the Royals. Shimron Hetmyer's display of power and skill in the death, though, has done RR a world of good. He's striking at close to 200 and has contributed in all four games so far. Gujarat will want to contain him in the death, with Rashid having the wood over him, but GT may have vital strategic decisions to make as to how Rashid should be used. Commentary Text: Ferguson to Samson, out Samson Run Out!! Direct-hit and Samson is a goner here! 150.4kph, Samson drives a full ball to mid-off and sets off for a non-existent single. Hardik Pandya swoops in from mid-off and hits the bulls-eye at the bowler's end to catch his counterpart well short of his ground. Gujarat are cock-a-hoop! Samson run out (Hardik Pandya) 11(11) [6s-1]

One aspect that has hurt GT has been their opening stand which hasn't survived a powerplay so far. In the four games, their first-wicket stands have been worth: 4, 2, 32 and 24. Left-hander Sai Sudarshan batting at No.3 now provides break in the run of right-handers at the top. Matthew Wade will likely make way for Rahmanullah Gurbaz, considering his inability to get starts so far and factoring in the latter's superior record in Asia. Gurbaz, in 68 innings, has amassed 1620 runs at an average of 24.17, striking at a dangerous 151.82 as opposed to Wade's 93.36. The middle-order too has been needing to get among the runs with David Miller yet to fire.  Samson too has had little success after the first game; it's evident he's struggling when pace is taken off in what has been his slowest start to a season in the last six years. His game has been found wanting on slower tracks in the past, and with tracks set to slow down as the season progress, his form could be a cause of concern for the Royals. Shimron Hetmyer's display of power and skill in the death, though, has done RR a world of good. He's striking at close to 200 and has contributed in all four games so far. Gujarat will want to contain him in the death, with Rashid having the wood over him, but GT may have vital strategic decisions to make as to how Rashid should be used.  When: RR vs GT, April 14, 19:30 IST  Where: Dr DY Patil Sports Academy, NaviMumbai  What to expect: The CSK-RCB game was played on a used wicket, with it being so dry that the dust on it was palpable. The spinners played a crucial role in the second innings with 7 wickets shared between Mahesh Theekshana and Ravindra Jadeja. If a similar wicket is on offer, both sides have the arsenal to use it to their advantage. The average first innings total has come down from 177 in 11 games in the first week (March 26-April 3) to 163 in 10 in the second week (April 4-11).  Team Watch:  Rajasthan Royals  Tactics & Matchups: Miller has struggled against both Chahal and Ashwin, falling to them thrice each. If RR's pacers strike early as they have so far in the season, then the spin duo will fancy their chance to break into the middle order early.  Probable XI: Jos Buttler, Yashasvi Jaiswal/Devdutt Padikkal, Sanju Samson (c & wk), Shimron Hetmyer, Riyan Parag, Ravichandran Ashwin, Jimmy Neesham, Navdeep Saini, Trent Boult, Prasidh Krishna, Yuzvendra Chahal  Gujarat Titans  B7$ Rashid Khan will have a big role to play in containing the dangerous Jos Buttler and later in the order, Shimron Hetmyer - both of who have been among the runs this season. Rashid has a good record against the two dismissing them four times, especially with Buttler averaging just 4.50 against the legspinner.  Probable XI: Rahmanullah Gurbaz/Matthew Wade (wk), Shubman Gill, Sai Sudharsan, Hardik Pandya (c), David Miller, Rahul Tewatia, Abhinav Manohar, Rashid Khan, Lockie Ferguson, Mohammed Shami, Darshan Nalkande  Did you know?  - There was seven first innings totals in excess of 170 in the first 11 matches and just two in the ten subsequent matches, both in Brabourne.  - Only Bumrah has taken more wickets than the duo of Rashid Khan and Yuzvendra Chahal in the last half-a-decade in the IPL. And in the middle overs, the two spinners sit on top of the wicket charts.  - Hetmyer has the second-highest strike-rate in death overs since IPL 2019 behind AB de Villiers. He strikes at 195.95 with a boundary percentage of 27.3.  What they said:  "The toss is not in our control. We are learning to adapt our game keeping the dew factor in mind. Both toss and the subsequent dew in the second half of the game is out of our hands," Padikkal said.
toss: Rajasthan Royals have won the toss and have opted to field

They're both tied on 6 points with three wins and a loss. Between both captains, Sanju Samson and Hardik Pandya, they've won just the one toss; RR are yet to chase in the tournament.  But most importantly, both sides' pacers have dominated the powerplay phase this season - with Trent Boult & Prasidh Krishna for RR, Mohammed Shami, Hardik Pandya and Lockie Ferguson for GT. RR's pacers have picked up 8 wickets, averaging 14.25, while GT's have 9 wickets at 17.00. Rashid Khan and Yuzvendra Chahal have been the most successful bowlers in the middle overs since IPL 2017, averaging 20.21 and 20.97 with 70 and 60 wickets respectively.  Gujarat, meanwhile, were handed their first loss of the season after an eight-wicket trouncing at the hands of the Sunrisers Hyderabad. One aspect that has hurt GT has been their opening stand which hasn't survived a powerplay so far. In the four games, their first-wicket stands have been worth: 4, 2, 32 and 24. Left-hander Sai Sudarshan batting at No.3 now provides break in the run of right-handers at the top. Matthew Wade will likely make way for Rahmanullah Gurbaz, considering his inability to get starts so far and factoring in the latter's superior record in Asia. Gurbaz, in 68 innings, has amassed 1620 runs at an average of 24.17, striking at a dangerous 151.82 as opposed to Wade's 93.36. The middle-order too has been needing to get among the runs with David Miller yet to fire.  Samson too has had little success after the first game; it's evident he's struggling when pace is taken off in what has been his slowest start to a season in the last six years. His game has been found wanting on slower tracks in the past, and with tracks set to slow down as the season progress, his form could be a cause of concern for the Royals. Shimron Hetmyer's display of power and skill in the death, though, has done RR a world of good. He's striking at close to 200 and has contributed in all four games so far. Gujarat will want to contain him in the death, with Rashid having the wood over him, but GT may have vital strategic decisions to make as to how Rashid should be used.  When: RR vs GT, April 14, 19:30 IST  Where: Dr DY Patil Sports Academy, NaviMumbai  What to expect: The CSK-RCB game was played on a used wicket, with it being so dry that the dust on it was palpable. The spinners played a crucial role in the second innings with 7 wickets shared between Mahesh Theekshana and Ravindra Jadeja. If a similar wicket is on offer, both sides have the arsenal to use it to their advantage. The average first innings total has come down from 177 in 11 games in the first week (March 26-April 3) to 163 in 10 in the second week (April 4-11).  Team Watch:  Rajasthan Royals  Tactics & Matchups: Miller has struggled against both Chahal and Ashwin, falling to them thrice each. If RR's pacers strike early as they have so far in the season, then the spin duo will fancy their chance to break into the middle order early.  Probable XI: Jos Buttler, Yashasvi Jaiswal/Devdutt Padikkal, Sanju Samson (c & wk), Shimron Hetmyer, Riyan Parag, Ravichandran Ashwin, Jimmy Neesham, Navdeep Saini, Trent Boult, Prasidh Krishna, Yuzvendra Chahal  Gujarat Titans  B7$ Rashid Khan will have a big role to play in containing the dangerous Jos Buttler and later in the order, Shimron Hetmyer - both of who have been among the runs this season. Rashid has a good record against the two dismissing them four times, especially with Buttler averaging just 4.50 against the legspinner.  Probable XI: Rahmanullah Gurbaz/Matthew Wade (wk), Shubman Gill, Sai Sudharsan, Hardik Pandya (c), David Miller, Rahul Tewatia, Abhinav Manohar, Rashid Khan, Lockie Ferguson, Mohammed Shami, Darshan Nalkande  Did you know?  - There was seven first innings totals in excess of 170 in the first 11 matches and just two in the ten subsequent matches, both in Brabourne.  - Only Bumrah has taken more wickets than the duo of Rashid Khan and Yuzvendra Chahal in the last half-a-decade in the IPL. And in the middle overs, the two spinners sit on top of the wicket charts.  - Hetmyer has the second-highest strike-rate in death overs since IPL 2019 behind AB de Villiers. He strikes at 195.95 with a boundary percentage of 27.3.  What they said:  "The toss is not in our control. We are learning to adapt our game keeping the dew factor in mind. Both toss and the subsequent dew in the second half of the game is out of our hands," Padikkal said.
toss: Rajasthan Royals have won the toss and have opted to field

Probable XI: Rahmanullah Gurbaz/Matthew Wade (wk), Shubman Gill, Sai Sudharsan, Hardik Pandya (c), David Miller, Rahul Tewatia, Abhinav Manohar, Rashid Khan, Lockie Ferguson, Mohammed Shami, Darshan Nalkande  Did you know?  - There was seven first innings totals in excess of 170 in the first 11 matches and just two in the ten subsequent matches, both in Brabourne.  - Only Bumrah has taken more wickets than the duo of Rashid Khan and Yuzvendra Chahal in the last half-a-decade in the IPL. And in the middle overs, the two spinners sit on top of the wicket charts.  - Hetmyer has the second-highest strike-rate in death overs since IPL 2019 behind AB de Villiers. He strikes at 195.95 with a boundary percentage of 27.3.  What they said:  "The toss is not in our control. We are learning to adapt our game keeping the dew factor in mind. Both toss and the subsequent dew in the second half of the game is out of our hands," Padikkal said.
team_b_subs: Preview by Kritika Naidu  The overview:  Little separates Rajasthan Royals and the Gujarat Titans after four games in the 2022 edition. They're both tied on 6 points with three wins and a loss. Between both captains, Sanju Samson and Hardik Pandya, they've won just the one toss; RR are yet to chase in the tournament.  But most importantly, both sides' pacers have dominated the powerplay phase this season - with Trent Boult & Prasidh Krishna for RR, Mohammed Shami, Hardik Pandya and Lockie Ferguson for GT. RR's pacers have picked up 8 wickets, averaging 14.25, while GT's have 9 wickets at 17.00. Rashid Khan and Yuzvendra Chahal have been the most successful bowlers in the middle overs since IPL 2017, averaging 20.21 and 20.97 with 70 and 60 wickets respectively.  Gujarat, meanwhile, were handed their first loss of the season after an eight-wicket trouncing at the hands of the Sunrisers Hyderabad. One aspect that has hurt GT has been their opening stand which hasn't survived a powerplay so far. In the four games, their first-wicket stands have been worth: 4, 2, 32 and 24. Left-hander Sai Sudarshan batting at No.3 now provides break in the run of right-handers at the top. Matthew Wade will likely make way for Rahmanullah Gurbaz, considering his inability to get starts so far and factoring in the latter's superior record in Asia. Gurbaz, in 68 innings, has amassed 1620 runs at an average of 24.17, striking at a dangerous 151.82 as opposed to Wade's 93.36. The middle-order too has been needing to get among the runs with David Miller yet to fire.  Samson too has had little success after the first game; it's evident he's struggling when pace is taken off in what has been his slowest start to a season in the last six years. His game has been found wanting on slower tracks in the past, and with tracks set to slow down as the season progress, his form could be a cause of concern for the Royals. Shimron Hetmyer's display of power and skill in the death, though, has done RR a world of good. He's striking at close to 200 and has contributed in all four games so far. Gujarat will want to contain him in the death, with Rashid having the wood over him, but GT may have vital strategic decisions to make as to how Rashid should be used.  When: RR vs GT, April 14, 19:30 IST  Where: Dr DY Patil Sports Academy, NaviMumbai  What to expect: The CSK-RCB game was played on a used wicket, with it being so dry that the dust on it was palpable. The spinners played a crucial role in the second innings with 7 wickets shared between Mahesh Theekshana and Ravindra Jadeja. If a similar wicket is on offer, both sides have the arsenal to use it to their advantage. The average first innings total has come down from 177 in 11 games in the first week (March 26-April 3) to 163 in 10 in the second week (April 4-11).  Team Watch:  Rajasthan Royals  Tactics & Matchups: Miller has struggled against both Chahal and Ashwin, falling to them thrice each. If RR's pacers strike early as they have so far in the season, then the spin duo will fancy their chance to break into the middle order early.  Probable XI: Jos Buttler, Yashasvi Jaiswal/Devdutt Padikkal, Sanju Samson (c & wk), Shimron Hetmyer, Riyan Parag, Ravichandran Ashwin, Jimmy Neesham, Navdeep Saini, Trent Boult, Prasidh Krishna, Yuzvendra Chahal  Gujarat Titans  B7$ Rashid Khan will have a big role to play in containing the dangerous Jos Buttler and later in the order, Shimron Hetmyer - both of who have been among the runs this season. Commentary Text: Ferguson to Buttler, out Bowled!! Wow! What a response from Lockie Ferguson! Deceives the half-centurion with a slower delivery and he's pumped up. 126.4kph, off-speed and in the blockhole, was the leg-cutter from Ferguson and Buttler fails to dig it out. The ball beats the outside edge to crash into the base of off and middle. Massive wicket, this! Buttler b Ferguson 54(24) [4s-8 6s-3]

Commentary Text: Ferguson to Buttler, SIX, 23-ball fifty for Jos Buttler! His team-mates in the dug-out stand and applaud. Length ball, Buttler shuffles across and uses the bowler's pace to scoop it over fine leg. There was a fielder in the deep but he could only watch the ball go over him

Gujarat will want to contain him in the death, with Rashid having the wood over him, but GT may have vital strategic decisions to make as to how Rashid should be used.  When: RR vs GT, April 14, 19:30 IST  Where: Dr DY Patil Sports Academy, NaviMumbai  What to expect: The CSK-RCB game was played on a used wicket, with it being so dry that the dust on it was palpable. The spinners played a crucial role in the second innings with 7 wickets shared between Mahesh Theekshana and Ravindra Jadeja. If a similar wicket is on offer, both sides have the arsenal to use it to their advantage. The average first innings total has come down from 177 in 11 games in the first week (March 26-April 3) to 163 in 10 in the second week (April 4-11).  Team Watch:  Rajasthan Royals  Tactics & Matchups: Miller has struggled against both Chahal and Ashwin, falling to them thrice each. If RR's pacers strike early as they have so far in the season, then the spin duo will fancy their chance to break into the middle order early.  Probable XI: Jos Buttler, Yashasvi Jaiswal/Devdutt Padikkal, Sanju Samson (c & wk), Shimron Hetmyer, Riyan Parag, Ravichandran Ashwin, Jimmy Neesham, Navdeep Saini, Trent Boult, Prasidh Krishna, Yuzvendra Chahal  Gujarat Titans  B7$ Rashid Khan will have a big role to play in containing the dangerous Jos Buttler and later in the order, Shimron Hetmyer - both of who have been among the runs this season. Rashid has a good record against the two dismissing them four times, especially with Buttler averaging just 4.50 against the legspinner.  Probable XI: Rahmanullah Gurbaz/Matthew Wade (wk), Shubman Gill, Sai Sudharsan, Hardik Pandya (c), David Miller, Rahul Tewatia, Abhinav Manohar, Rashid Khan, Lockie Ferguson, Mohammed Shami, Darshan Nalkande  Did you know?  - There was seven first innings totals in excess of 170 in the first 11 matches and just two in the ten subsequent matches, both in Brabourne.  - Only Bumrah has taken more wickets than the duo of Rashid Khan and Yuzvendra Chahal in the last half-a-decade in the IPL. And in the middle overs, the two spinners sit on top of the wicket charts.  - Hetmyer has the second-highest strike-rate in death overs since IPL 2019 behind AB de Villiers. He strikes at 195.95 with a boundary percentage of 27.3.  What they said:  "The toss is not in our control. We are learning to adapt our game keeping the dew factor in mind. Both toss and the subsequent dew in the second half of the game is out of our hands," Padikkal said.

Matthew Wade will likely make way for Rahmanullah Gurbaz, considering his inability to get starts so far and factoring in the latter's superior record in Asia. Gurbaz, in 68 innings, has amassed 1620 runs at an average of 24.17, striking at a dangerous 151.82 as opposed to Wade's 93.36. The middle-order too has been needing to get among the runs with David Miller yet to fire.  Samson too has had little success after the first game; it's evident he's struggling when pace is taken off in what has been his slowest start to a season in the last six years. His game has been found wanting on slower tracks in the past, and with tracks set to slow down as the season progress, his form could be a cause of concern for the Royals. Shimron Hetmyer's display of power and skill in the death, though, has done RR a world of good. He's striking at close to 200 and has contributed in all four games so far. Gujarat will want to contain him in the death, with Rashid having the wood over him, but GT may have vital strategic decisions to make as to how Rashid should be used.  When: RR vs GT, April 14, 19:30 IST  Where: Dr DY Patil Sports Academy, NaviMumbai  What to expect: The CSK-RCB game was played on a used wicket, with it being so dry that the dust on it was palpable. The spinners played a crucial role in the second innings with 7 wickets shared between Mahesh Theekshana and Ravindra Jadeja. If a similar wicket is on offer, both sides have the arsenal to use it to their advantage. The average first innings total has come down from 177 in 11 games in the first week (March 26-April 3) to 163 in 10 in the second week (April 4-11).  Team Watch:  Rajasthan Royals  Tactics & Matchups: Miller has struggled against both Chahal and Ashwin, falling to them thrice each. If RR's pacers strike early as they have so far in the season, then the spin duo will fancy their chance to break into the middle order early.  Probable XI: Jos Buttler, Yashasvi Jaiswal/Devdutt Padikkal, Sanju Samson (c & wk), Shimron Hetmyer, Riyan Parag, Ravichandran Ashwin, Jimmy Neesham, Navdeep Saini, Trent Boult, Prasidh Krishna, Yuzvendra Chahal  Gujarat Titans  B7$ Rashid Khan will have a big role to play in containing the dangerous Jos Buttler and later in the order, Shimron Hetmyer - both of who have been among the runs this season. Rashid has a good record against the two dismissing them four times, especially with Buttler averaging just 4.50 against the legspinner.  Probable XI: Rahmanullah Gurbaz/Matthew Wade (wk), Shubman Gill, Sai Sudharsan, Hardik Pandya (c), David Miller, Rahul Tewatia, Abhinav Manohar, Rashid Khan, Lockie Ferguson, Mohammed Shami, Darshan Nalkande  Did you know?  - There was seven first innings totals in excess of 170 in the first 11 matches and just two in the ten subsequent matches, both in Brabourne.  - Only Bumrah has taken more wickets than the duo of Rashid Khan and Yuzvendra Chahal in the last half-a-decade in the IPL. And in the middle overs, the two spinners sit on top of the wicket charts.  - Hetmyer has the second-highest strike-rate in death overs since IPL 2019 behind AB de Villiers. He strikes at 195.95 with a boundary percentage of 27.3.  What they said:  "The toss is not in our control. We are learning to adapt our game keeping the dew factor in mind. Both toss and the subsequent dew in the second half of the game is out of our hands," Padikkal said.

Commentary Text: Ferguson to Ashwin, out Caught by Miller!! Miller takes an outstanding catch and Ferguson strikes first ball! Overpitched outside off, Ashwin stays deep and slightly clears his front leg to batter it through the covers. Doesn't bother to keep it down and pays the price. Miller, at shortish cover, dives to his left and takes a low, sharp catch with both hands. It was travelling at a brisk pace and he showed great reflexes. Ashwin gone for a run-a-ball eight. The experiment to promote him didn't work today. Ashwin c Miller b Ferguson 8(8) [6s-1]

Commentary Text: Rashid Khan to Buttler, no run, confident and vociferous appeal for lbw. Wade reckons it's spinning too much but Hardik sends it upstairs. Googly from Rashid Khan, Buttler doesn't pick it and plays down the wrong line as he goes back to defend. Missed the inside edge by a mile to rap him on the pads. The TV umpire doesn't even need UltraEdge. Over to ball-tracking. Wickets - umpire's call and the onfield call stays. GT don't lose a review. Ball-tracking shows it be clipping leg. Buttler survives!
team_a_11: Rajasthan Royals (Playing XI): Jos Buttler, Devdutt Padikkal, Sanju Samson(w/c), Rassie van der Dussen, Shimron Hetmyer, James Neesham, Riyan Parag, Ravichandran Ashwin, Kuldeep Sen, Prasidh Krishna, Yuzvendra Chahal
